prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For the HCO+, HCN 4-3 and CS 7-6 lines the requirement to accurately constrain the kinematics of the envelope, disk and outflow from the line peak, width, shape and wings mandate a velocity resolution of 0.12 km/s so that the lines will be significantly resolved even at radii of 7.5" where the line-width may be less do to material at larger distances from the central protostar moving more slowly. For H13CN we select a resolution of 0.2 km/s since this line is the faintest and optically thin so will have a less complex line profile. We select the full bandwidth in this line to ensuring >1 GHz aggregate bandwidth to enable standard calibration. Selecting a lower resolution for any of the lines would not provide enough resolution elements to accurately constrain the line shape and thus the gas kinematics.

The smallest spatial scale (0.3") is chosen to ensure that we resolve with several beams the IRAS4A binary (1.7") as well as giving us the most discriminating power on the kinematics and probing disk (i.e. 100AU) scales. The largest angular resolution (15") is chosen to ensure that we can reliably trace material from radii of ~1500AU in both sources, allowing us to link to the large-scale infall constrained from single-dish observations.
The northern location of IRAS4A means that there will be some elongation of the beam will not be too severe as to prevent out analysis of the data. As the source with the highest observed infall velociy this is the best source to target for our science. Due to the declination there will some shadowing of the ACA, but the ACA is absolutely critical to our science so longer will likely be needed to reach the required sensitivity.

The sensitivity in the band 7 observations is dictated by the weakest line, H13CN 4-3. The peak flux density for NGC1333-IRAS2A from the SMA is 1.2 Jy/beam in a 1.2x1.0" beam (Jorgensen et al., 2005, ApJ, 632, 973), which corresponds to 8K. The molecular line fluxes for IRAS2A are found to be similar to other Class 0 protostars including IRAS4A in the SMA PROSAC survey (Jorgensen et al., 2007, 659, 479). As we want to detect the line at 10 sigma at the peak and above 3 sigma further from the protostars in order to constrain the kinematics of the line, we conservatively estimate a requirement of 0.8K or 7 mJy/beam. All other lines are observed to be brighter in both single-dish and interferometic data towards Class 0 protostars, so all will be well detected.
The line widths (0.12 km/s in HCO+, HCN and CS and 0.2 km/s in H13CN) are chosen to maximise our ability to accurately constrain the line shape and thus the gas kinematics. Full basebands in all lines are chosen to ensure >1GHz aggregate bandwidth, while spectral averaging is used to ameliorate the data rate as much as possible.
Continuum: The peak continuum flux density was calculated assuming that the flux density detected towards the fainter component (A2) by Jorgensen et al. (2007) of 2.4Jy at 1.3mm in a 1.2"x1.2" beam is evenly distributed within the SMA beam.

Our science mandates that we accurately constrain the line profile shapes in order to constrain the gas kinematics. Given the expected line shapes (see Fig. 2 of science case) we therefore need the selected velocity resolution. There is no way to fulfil this requirement and ensure >1 GHz aggregate bandwidth without going over the data rate limit. Spectral averaging has been used by a factor of 2 for the HCO+, HCN and CS lines to lower the data rate as much as possible, but lowering the spectral resolution any further in any line will make constraining the line shape almost impossible given the narrow structure induced by infall.

For the 12CO, 13CO and C18O J=2-1, and H2CO 303-202 lines the requirement to accurately constrain the kinematics of the envelope, disk and outflow from the line peak, width, shape and wings mandate a velocity resolution of 0.16 km/s so that the lines will be significantly resolved even at radii of 7.5" where the line-width may be less do to material at larger distances from the central protostar moving more slowly. For H2CO 322-2_21 and 321-220, since we only require detections then we spectrally average by a factor of 4 to 0.33 km/s resolution. We do not smooth further than this to ensure that we do not dilute the lines unnecessarily.

The smallest spatial scale (0.3") is chosen to ensure that we resolve with several beams the IRAS4A binary (1.7") as well as giving us the most discriminating power on the kinematics and probing disk (i.e. 100AU) scales. The largest angular resolution (15") is chosen to ensure that we can reliably trace material from radii of ~1500AU in both sources, allowing us to link to the large-scale infall constrained from single-dish observations.
The northern location of IRAS4A means that there will be some elongation of the beam will not be too severe as to prevent out analysis of the data. As the source with the highest observed infall velociy this is the best source to target for our science. Due to the declination there will some shadowing of the ACA, but the ACA is absolutely critical to our science so longer will likely be needed to reach the required sensitivity.

Since the H2CO 322-221 and 321-220 lines will be used to constrain the temperature in the inner regions but not the kinematics, these lines are spetrally averaged to 0.3km/s resolution while all other, brighter lines which will be used for kinematic analysis are observed at 0.16km/s resolution. The bandwidths around the lines are chosen to ensure that there is sufficient band-width to constrain the outflow wings while still leaving sufficient line-free channels for the continuum and good spectral baselines to be determined.
The sensitivity in the band 6 setting (1K or 3.5 mJy/beam in 0.3km\s bins) is dictated by detecting the faintest of the three H2CO lines at better than 3 sigma at the peak. The peak flux was calculated using a RATRAN model with density and temperature profile from Kristensen et al. (2012, A&A, 542,8), kinematic properties from Mottram et al. (2013, A&A, 558, 126) and conservative H2CO abundance based on the results of Jorgensen et al. (2004, A&A, 416, 603) which when convolved to the correct beam are comparable with single-dish observations. Based on this model, this line should be detected above 1 sigma out to a radius of ~1". Since the H2CO 322-221 and 321-220 lines have the same upper energy level, in the unlikely event that the abundance is lower than expected we will stack the lines to gain a detection. All other lines will be well detected at the requested sensitivity in 0.16 km/s bins, even in the line wings, out to beyond a radius of 7.5" based on similar observations of BHR71 at lower spatial resolution (1.3x1.2") with ALMA as part of project 2013.1.00518.S and the fact that IRAS4A is brighter than BHR71 in single-dish observations of these lines.
Continuum: The peak continuum flux density was calculated assuming that the flux density detected towards the fainter component (A2) by Jorgensen et al. (2007) of 1.0Jy at 0.8mm in a 1.2"x1.2" beam is evenly distributed within the SMA beam.

For the HCO+, HCN 4-3 and CS 7-6 lines the requirement to accurately constrain the kinematics of the envelope, disk and outflow from the line peak, width, shape and wings mandate a velocity resolution of 0.12 km/s so that the lines will be significantly resolved even at radii of 7.5" where the line-width may be less do to material at larger distances from the central protostar moving more slowly. For H13CN we select a resolution of 0.2 km/s since this line is the faintest and optically thin so will have a less complex line profile. We select the full bandwidth in this line to ensuring >1 GHz aggregate bandwidth to enable standard calibration. Selecting a lower resolution for any of the lines would not provide enough resolution elements to accurately constrain the line shape and thus the gas kinematics.

The smallest spatial scale (0.3") is chosen to ensure that we resolve with several beams the IRAS4A binary (1.7") as well as giving us the most discriminating power on the kinematics and probing disk (i.e. 100AU) scales. We use the same resolution for BHR71 in order to ensure direct comparisons can be made between it and IRAS4A. The largest angular resolution (15") is chosen to ensure that we can reliably trace material from radii of ~1500AU in both sources, allowing us to link to the large-scale infall constrained from single-dish observations.

The sensitivity in the band 7 observations is dictated by the weakest line, H13CN 4-3. The peak flux density for NGC1333-IRAS2A from the SMA is 1.2 Jy/beam in a 1.2x1.0" beam (Jorgensen et al., 2005, ApJ, 632, 973), which corresponds to 8K. The molecular line fluxes for IRAS2A are found to be similar to other Class 0 protostars in the SMA PROSAC survey (Jorgensen et al., 2007, 659, 479). As we want to detect the line at 10 sigma at the peak and above 3 sigma further from the protostars in order to constrain the kinematics of the line, we conservatively estimate a requirement of 0.8K or 7 mJy/beam. All other lines are observed to be brighter in both single-dish and interferometic data towards Class 0 protostars, so all will be well detected.
The line widths (0.12 km/s in HCO+, HCN and CS and 0.2 km/s in H13CN) are chosen to maximise our ability to accurately constrain the line shape and thus the gas kinematics. Full basebands in all lines are chosen to ensure >1GHz aggregate bandwidth, while spectral averaging is used to ameliorate the data rate as much as possible.
Continuum: The peak continuum flux density is estimated from the observed ALMA flux in band 6 in a 1.3x1.2" beam of 0.48 Jy/beam from project 2013.1.00518.S. assuming a dust spectral index of 1.

Our science mandates that we accurately constrain the line profile shapes in order to constrain the gas kinematics. Given the expected line shapes (see Fig. 2 of science case) we therefore need the selected velocity resolution. There is no way to fulfil this requirement and ensure >1 GHz aggregate bandwidth without going over the data rate limit. Spectral averaging has been used by a factor of 2 for the HCO+, HCN and CS lines to lower the data rate as much as possible, but lowering the spectral resolution any further in any line will make constraining the line shape almost impossible given the narrow structure induced by infall.

For the 12CO, 13CO and C18O J=2-1, and H2CO 303-202 lines the requirement to accurately constrain the kinematics of the envelope, disk and outflow from the line peak, width, shape and wings mandate a velocity resolution of 0.16 km/s so that the lines will be significantly resolved even at radii of 7.5" where the line-width may be less do to material at larger distances from the central protostar moving more slowly. For H2CO 322-2_21 and 321-220, since we only require detections then we spectrally average by a factor of 4 to 0.33 km/s resolution. We do not smooth further than this to ensure that we do not dilute the lines unnecessarily.

The smallest spatial scale (0.3") is chosen to ensure that we resolve with several beams the IRAS4A binary (1.7") as well as giving us the most discriminating power on the kinematics and probing disk (i.e. 100AU) scales. We use the same resolution for BHR71 in order to ensure direct comparisons can be made between it and IRAS4A. The largest angular resolution (15") is chosen to ensure that we can reliably trace material from radii of ~1500AU in both sources, allowing us to link to the large-scale infall constrained from single-dish observations.

Since the H2CO 322-221 and 321-220 lines will be used to constrain the temperature in the inner regions but not the kinematics, these lines are spectrally averaged to 0.3km/s resolution while all other, brighter lines which will be used for kinematic analysis are observed at 0.16km/s resolution. The bandwidths around the lines are chosen to ensure that there is sufficient band-width to constrain the outflow wings while still leaving sufficient line-free channels for the continuum and good spectral baselines to be determined.
The sensitivity in the band 6 setting (1K or 3.5 mJy/beam in 0.3km\s bins) is dictated by detecting the faintest of the three H2CO lines at better than 3 sigma at the peak. The peak flux was calculated using a RATRAN model with density and temperature profile from Kristensen et al. (2012, A&A, 542,8), kinematic properties from Mottram et al. (2013, A&A, 558, 126) and conservative H2CO abundance based on the results of Jorgensen et al. (2004, A&A, 416, 603) which when convolved to the correct beam are comparable with single-dish observations. Based on this model, this line should be detected above 1 sigma out to a radius of ~1". Since the H2CO 322-221 and 321-220 lines have the same upper energy level, in the unlikely event that the abundance is lower than expected we will stack the lines to gain a detection. All other lines will be well detected at the requested sensitivity in 0.16 km/s bins, even in the line wings, out to beyond a radius of 7.5" based on similar observations of BHR71 at lower spatial resolution (1.3x1.2") with ALMA as part of project 2013.1.00518.S.
Continuum: The peak continuum flux density is estimated from the observed ALMA flux in band 6 in a 1.3x1.2" beam of 0.48 Jy/beam from project 2013.1.00518.S.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The path and rate at which material in YSOs falls from the gravitationally bound envelope (10,000AU scales) to the rotationally flattened disk (100AU scales) has a dramatic impact on the properties, evolution and chemical composition of the disk and protostar. High angular momentum can facilitate the development of a stable Keplerian disk while high mass infall rates can induce instabilities which lead to episodic accretion and Rossby wave instabilities which aid grain growth and planet formation. Despite this strong influence, very few observational constraints have been placed on how and how fast material moves towards the disk, particularly on 1000 to 100 AU scales. We propose to constrain the rate and route of mass infall, as well as the contributions to the gas kinematics from rotation and outflow, in two ideal Class 0 protostellar candidates, NGC1333-IRAS4A and BHR71. These are known to have high mass infall rates on large scales from single-dish observations. The selected lines will allow us to constrain the temperature, column density and velocity distributions of these two protostars, thus revealing the details of how material gets onto the disk for the first time.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
Center for Astronomy, Heidelberg, University of
